bibl.title: Letter from [Howard A. Kelly] to A.S. von Mansfelde, December 13, 1906

div1.p: [Kelly] offers his views about the credit due Carroll. Kelly proposes to support Carroll's promotion on the basis of his merits alone without diminishing the role played by Reed.

div1.head: Letter from [Howard A. Kelly] to A.S. von Mansfelde, December 13, 1906
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
In answer to a letter of Dr.
Von Mansfelde of Dec. 12, returned
to him by his request.
Dec. 13th, 1906
Dear Dr. Von Mansfelde:-
div1.p:
I would like to help Dr.
Carroll in every possible way, and no one is more
interested in advancing his interests than I am,
but I see that you are interested.

I will gladly take any steps to make the
President or anyone else see that Dr. Carroll
deserves promotion. It is, of course, true that
he and Lazear were most invaluable associates in
the work and Dr. Reed was most fortunate in hav-
ing such co-laborers. I recently took occasion
at the Reed Banquet in Brooklyn, to speak
particularly of Carroll's merits. If the attempt
is made, however, to detract from Reed's credit
in the matter, that will only hurt Carroll and
arouse strong opposition in all parts of the
country. I have already heard growlings to this
effect. / The matter is a delicate one and will
have to be very delicately managed and without
the slightest detraction from Reed.

In bringing forward Carroll's merits, it
will not be necessary to make any invidious
comparisons, he has done enough good work to
stand on his own feet in this matter. If it is
taken up in this spirit, I will gladly help.
If the matter is taken up in a bitter spirit
count me out of it entirely, for it will then
regulate itself and, as I clearly foresee, to
Carroll's great detriment. Nothing that can
be done can break down even one jot or tittle of
the credit the country has accorded Reed. A
great deal can be done to make the country realize
x from a warm friend of Carroll's
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY.
2.
what an invaluable associate he had in Carroll
and what a noble, self-sacrificing man Carroll
showed himself to be.

As far as the Life of Reed goes, I would
heartily welcome the fullest criticism, and no
matter what might be said about it would, myself,
have no unkindly feeling even though I consider-
ed the criticism not well-founded. I say this
because I went over the matter most carefully
with the data before me. If you go to Havana, you
will find that the Cubans feel about Findlay
as you do about Carroll.
